unnormalised: Navigating the world of Obstetrics and Gynecology (OBGYN) can feel overwhelming, especially with all the medical jargon. As Dr. Meena Sharma always says, understanding the basics empowers you to take control of your health journey. So, let’s demystify some common terms and scenarios.
normalised: Navigating the world of Obstetrics and Gynecology (O-B-G-Y-N) can feel overwhelming, especially with all the medical jargon. As Doctor Meena Sharma always says, understanding the basics empowers you to take control of your health journey. So, let’s demystify some common terms and scenarios.

unnormalised: First up, prenatal care. This refers to the healthcare you receive during pregnancy. Ideally, you should start prenatal visits around 6-8 wks after your last menstrual period. During these visits, your OBGYN will monitor your and your baby's health, perform routine tests like BP (blood pressure) checks, and provide guidance on nutrition and lifestyle.
normalised: First up, prenatal care. This refers to the healthcare you receive during pregnancy. Ideally, you should start prenatal visits around six to eight weeks after your last menstrual period. During these visits, your O-B-G-Y-N will monitor your and your baby's health, perform routine tests like B-P (blood pressure) checks, and provide guidance on nutrition and lifestyle.

unnormalised: Then there's labor and delivery. Labor can be divided into 3 stages. Stage 1 involves cervical dilation, which ideally should reach 10 cm for vaginal delivery. Stage 2 is the actual delivery of the baby, and Stage 3 is the delivery of the placenta. Different methods of pain management are available, including epidurals.
normalised: Then there's labor and delivery. Labor can be divided into three stages. Stage one involves cervical dilation, which ideally should reach ten centimeter for vaginal delivery. Stage two is the actual delivery of the baby, and Stage three is the delivery of the placenta. Different methods of pain management are available, including epidurals.

unnormalised: Postpartum care, or care after childbirth, is just as important. You'll have a postpartum check-up around 6 wks after delivery. Common concerns include postpartum depression, breastfeeding difficulties, and recovery from episiotomies (if performed during delivery). Remember, it's crucial to seek support from your healthcare provider or a support group if you're struggling.

unnormalised: Now, let’s talk about gynecological health beyond pregnancy. Regular check-ups are key for detecting any potential issues early. A Pap smear, typically done every 3 yrs (or every 5 yrs if combined with an HPV test), screens for cervical cancer. These tests are recommended starting at age 21.
normalised: Now, let’s talk about gynecological health beyond pregnancy. Regular check-ups are key for detecting any potential issues early. A Pap smear, typically done every three years (or every five years if combined with an H-P-V test), screens for cervical cancer. These tests are recommended starting at age twenty one.

unnormalised: Common gynecological issues include PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome), endometriosis, and fibroids. PCOS can affect your menstrual cycle and fertility. Endometriosis involves the growth of uterine tissue outside the uterus, causing pain and other complications. Fibroids are non-cancerous growths in the uterus. These conditions can often be managed with medication or, in some cases, surgery.
normalised: Common gynecological issues include P-C-O-S (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome), endometriosis, and fibroids. P-C-O-S can affect your menstrual cycle and fertility. Endometriosis involves the growth of uterine tissue outside the uterus, causing pain and other complications. Fibroids are non-cancerous growths in the uterus. These conditions can often be managed with medication or, in some cases, surgery.

unnormalised: Don't hesitate to prepone a visit to your gynaecologist if you experience any unusual symptoms such as abnormal bleeding, pelvic pain, or changes in your menstrual cycle. Also, remember that vaccinations, such as the HPV vaccine, are an important part of preventative care and are typically administered in 2 doses between the ages of 11 and 12 or 3 doses up to age 26.
